@graph.rdfs:label: Sparks
@graph.text_span: We present Sparks, a multi-modal multi-agent AI model that executes the entire discovery cycle that includes hypothesis generation, experiment design and iterative refinement to develop generalizable principles and a report without human intervention.:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

@graph.rdfs:label: Median maximum unfolding force at 80 amino acids (beta-sheet-rich peptides)
@graph.text_span: At a peptide length of 80 amino acids, β-sheets achieved a median Fmax of 0.399 (CI: [0.303, 0.417]), overtaking α-helices, which reached 0.313 (CI: [0.313, 0.379]).:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

@graph.rdfs:label: Median maximum RMSD at 60 amino acids (alpha-helix-rich peptides)
@graph.text_span: The median RMSD for α designs increases from 2.86 Å at 40 aa to a peak of 4.00 Å at 60 aa, then declines to 2.44–2.80 Å at 100–120 aa.:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

natural_language_summary: Sparks, a multi-modal multi-agent AI system, autonomously discovered new protein design principles through iterative self-driven research. The knowledge graph captures a length-dependent mechanical crossover: beyond roughly 80 amino acids, beta-sheet-rich peptides exhibit higher unfolding force than alpha-helix-rich peptides. It also encodes a chain length vs. stability map, where beta-sheet architectures maintain low maximum RMSD (indicating high stability) even as sequences grow, whereas mixed alpha/beta structures show a "frustration zone" of high structural variability at intermediate lengths. Key entities include the Sparks model and peptide classes (alpha-helix-rich, beta-sheet-rich, mixed), linked by semantic relations to measured attributes such as unfolding force and RMSD that substantiate these findings.
